content:
UpDownBase Class

Definition

Implements the basic functionality required by a spin box (also known as an up-down control).

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.Designer("System.Windows.Forms.Design.UpDownBaseDesigner, System.Design, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a")]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterface(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterfaceType.AutoDispatch)]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(true)]
public abstract class UpDownBase : System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl

Remarks

A spin box consists of a text box and a small vertical scroll bar, commonly referred to as a spin button control. The UpDownBase class links the two controls and allows the user to change the display in the text box by clicking the up or down buttons or by entering the appropriate type of value directly into the text box. Use the spin box in cases where you want to limit the list of values a user can select, similar to a list box or combo box. Depending upon the type of list you want to display, the advantage to using a spin box is that it allows you to quickly set a range of valid values, rather than adding items one at a time. Implementing a spin box requires less data validation than a text box, as you can limit the data type when you derive a class from UpDownBase. An example of this is the NumericUpDown class, which limits the values to the numeric type and uses a Minimum and Maximum property to validate the data.

To allow the user to use the arrow keys to change the contents of a spin box, set the InterceptArrowKeys property to true. To restrict the user to values you specify, set the ReadOnly property to true. To control the alignment of text in the spin box, set the TextAlign property. To set the alignment of the up and down buttons in relation to the text box portion of the control, set the UpDownAlign property to either LeftRightAlignment or LeftRightAlignment.

The UpButton and DownButton methods, when overridden, handle the clicking of the up or down buttons. When overridden, the ValidateEditText and UpdateEditText methods validate the value (either selected or entered) and update the text displayed in the spin box. If the value fails validation, use the Select method to select the text that is not valid. This allows the user to quickly correct the text by simply typing in a new value without having to manually select or delete the existing text.

Starting with the .NET Framework 4.6, the UpDownBase control will be resized based on the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry: 

<appSettings>  
  <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" />  
</appSettings>

Constructors

UpDownBase()

Initializes a new instance of the UpDownBase class.

public UpDownBase ();

Properties

AutoScroll

Gets a value indicating whether the container will allow the user to scroll to any controls placed outside of its visible boundaries.

public override bool AutoScroll { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

false in all cases.

Remarks

The UpDownBase control does not use the AutoScroll property.

AutoScrollMargin

Gets or sets the size of the auto-scroll margin.

public System.Drawing.Size AutoScrollMargin { get; set; }
Value
Size

A Size that represents the height and width, in pixels, of the auto-scroll margin.

Exceptions
ArgumentException

The stem.Drawing.Size.Height* or stem.Drawing.Size.Width* is less than 0.

Remarks

The UpDownBase control does not use the AutoScrollMargin property.

AutoScrollMinSize

Gets or sets the minimum size of the auto-scroll area.

public System.Drawing.Size AutoScrollMinSize { get; set; }
Value
Size

A Size that represents the minimum height and width, in pixels, of the scroll bars.

Remarks

The UpDownBase control does not use the AutoScrollMinSize property.

AutoSize

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the control should automatically resize based on its contents.

public override bool AutoSize { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true to indicate the control should automatically resize based on its contents; otherwise, false.

BackColor

Gets or sets the background color for the text box portion of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Drawing.Color BackColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

A Color that represents the background color of the text box portion of the spin box.

BackgroundImage

Gets or sets the background image for the UpDownBase.

public override System.Drawing.Image BackgroundImage { get; set; }
Value
Image

The background image for the UpDownBase.

Remarks

The BackgroundImage property has no effect on the appearance of the UpDownBase control; therefore, it is hidden in the designer and from IntelliSense.

BackgroundImageLayout

Gets or sets the layout of the stem.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.BackgroundImage* of the UpDownBase.

public override System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout BackgroundImageLayout { get; set; }
Value
ImageLayout

One of the ImageLayout values.

Remarks

The BackgroundImageLayout property has no effect on the appearance of the UpDownBase control; therefore, it is hidden in the designer and from IntelliSense.

BorderStyle

Gets or sets the border style for the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public System.Windows.Forms.BorderStyle BorderStyle { get; set; }
Value
BorderStyle

One of the BorderStyle values. The default value is BorderStyle.

Exceptions
InvalidEnumArgumentException

The value assigned is not one of the BorderStyle values.

Remarks

You can use the BorderStyle property to create borderless and flat controls in addition to the default three-dimensional control.

ChangingText

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the text property is being changed internally by its parent class.

protected bool ChangingText { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the stem.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text* property is being changed internally by the UpDownBase class; otherwise, false.

Remarks

The ChangingText property acts as a flag for the UpDownBase class. This property is used by derived classes to indicate when the class is changing the current Text property internally. If this property is set to false, the control requires that the user is changing the Text property and will set the UserEdit property to true.

ContextMenu

Gets or sets the shortcut menu associated with the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenu ContextMenu { get; set; }
Value
ContextMenu

The ContextMenu associated with the spin box.

Remarks

The preferred way to associate a shortcut menu with a tree node is with the ContextMenuStrip property.

ContextMenuStrip

Gets or sets the shortcut menu for the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenuStrip ContextMenuStrip { get; set; }
Value
ContextMenuStrip

The ContextMenuStrip associated with the control.

Remarks

The shortcut menu appears when the user right-clicks the spin box.

CreateParams

Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams CreateParams { get; }
Value
CreateParams

The creation parameters.

DefaultSize

Gets the default size of the control.

protected override System.Drawing.Size DefaultSize { get; }
Value
Size

The default Size of the control.

DockPadding

Gets the dock padding settings for all edges of the UpDownBase control.

public System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl.DockPaddingEdges DockPadding { get; }
Value

The dock paddings settings for this control.

Remarks

The UpDownBase control does not use the DockPadding property.

Focused

Gets a value indicating whether the control has input focus.

public override bool Focused { get; }
Value
Boolean

true if the control has focus; otherwise, false.

ForeColor

Gets or sets the foreground color of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Drawing.Color ForeColor { get; set; }
Value
Color

The foreground Color of the spin box.

Remarks

The ForeColor property will change the color of the text in the textbox portion of the spin box.

InterceptArrowKeys

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can use the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values.

public bool InterceptArrowKeys { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the control allows the use of the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values; otherwise, false. The default value is true.

Remarks

If the InterceptArrowKeys property is set to true and the spin box (also known as an up-down control) has focus, the user can use the UP ARROW and DOWN ARROW keys to select values.

MaximumSize

Gets or sets the maximum size of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Drawing.Size MaximumSize { get; set; }
Value
Size

The Size, which is the maximum size of the spin box.

Remarks

Regardless of the specified value, the Height of the maximum size will always be 0.

MinimumSize

Gets or sets the minimum size of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override System.Drawing.Size MinimumSize { get; set; }
Value
Size

The Size, which is the minimum size of the spin box.

PreferredHeight

Gets the height of the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public int PreferredHeight { get; }
Value
Int32

The height, in pixels, of the spin box.

Remarks

The PreferredHeight property value is based on the PreferredHeight property of the text box portion of the control and is adjusted for the style of border.

ReadOnly

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the text can be changed by the use of the up or down buttons only.

public bool ReadOnly { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the text can be changed by the use of the up or down buttons only; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

Remarks

By setting the ReadOnly property to true, you will eliminate the need for much validation of the Text property. The user will be restricted to the use of the up and down buttons to change the Text values. It will only allow them to select values you specify.

Note

In the derived class DomainUpDown, the behavior described is slightly different. When ReadOnly is set to true and a key is pressed, the control selects the first item in the collection where the first character matches the key pressed.

Text

Gets or sets the text displayed in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public override string Text { get; set; }
Value
String

The string value displayed in the spin box.

Remarks

The UpdateEditText method is called if the Text property is set while the UserEdit property is set to true. The ValidateEditText method is called if the Text property is set while the UserEdit property is set to false.

TextAlign

Gets or sets the alignment of the text in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public System.Windows.Forms.HorizontalAlignment TextAlign { get; set; }
Value
HorizontalAlignment

One of the HorizontalAlignment values. The default value is HorizontalAlignment.

Exceptions
InvalidEnumArgumentException

The value assigned is not one of the HorizontalAlignment values.

UpDownAlign

Gets or sets the alignment of the up and down buttons on the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public System.Windows.Forms.LeftRightAlignment UpDownAlign { get; set; }
Value
LeftRightAlignment

One of the LeftRightAlignment values. The default value is LeftRightAlignment.

Exceptions
InvalidEnumArgumentException

The value assigned is not one of the LeftRightAlignment values.

UserEdit

Gets or sets a value indicating whether a value has been entered by the user.

protected bool UserEdit { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the user has changed the stem.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.Text* property; otherwise, false.

Remarks

If the Text property is set while the UserEdit property is set to true, the UpdateEditText method is called. If the Text property is set while the UserEdit property is set to false, the ValidateEditText method is called.

Methods

DownButton()

When overridden in a derived class, handles the clicking of the down button on the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public abstract void DownButton ();

When overridden in a derived class, raises the Changed event.

Object

e
EventArgs

OnFontChanged(EventArgs)

Raises the FontChanged event.

protected override void OnFontChanged (EventArgs e);
e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnFontChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

mevent

A MouseEventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

If a double-click occurs, the OnMouseUp method will raise the DoubleClick event.

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnMouseUp method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

OnMouseWheel(MouseEventArgs)

Raises the MouseWheel event.

protected override void OnMouseWheel (System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs e);
e
MouseEventArgs

A MouseEventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

If the spin box (also known as an up-down control) has focus when this event occurs, the direction the user scrolled the mouse wheel is determined, and either the UpButton or DownButton method is called.

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnMouseWheel method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

OnTextBoxKeyDown(Object,KeyEventArgs)

Raises the KeyDown event.

protected virtual void OnTextBoxKeyDown (object source, System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventArgs e);
source
Object

The source of the event.

e
KeyEventArgs

A KeyEventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

If the InterceptArrowKeys property is set to true and the user presses the UP ARROW key, the UpButton method is called. Likewise, if the user presses the DOWN ARROW key, the DownButton method is called.

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnTextBoxKeyDown method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

Remarks

The OnTextBoxKeyPress method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

Raises the LostFocus event.

protected virtual void OnTextBoxLostFocus (object source, EventArgs e);
source
Object

The source of the event.

e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

This method validates the text in the text box portion of the control when the spin box (also known as an up-down control) loses focus.

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnTextBoxLostFocus method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

Raises the Resize event.

protected virtual void OnTextBoxResize (object source, EventArgs e);
source
Object

The source of the event.

e
EventArgs

An EventArgs that contains the event data.

Remarks

This method adjusts the size of the spin box (also known as an up-down control) when the text box portion of the control is resized.

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnTextBoxResize method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

protected virtual void OnTextBoxTextChanged (object source, EventArgs e);

e

Remarks

Select(Int32,Int32)

Selects a range of text in the spin box (also known as an up-down control) specifying the starting position and number of characters to select.

public void Select (int start, int length);
start
Int32

The position of the first character to be selected.

length
Int32

The total number of characters to be selected.

Remarks

The Select method can be used when the spin box gets focus, or when the Text property fails data validation. When adding the validation code for the ValidateEditText method in a derived class, call the Select method when validation fails.

UpButton()

When overridden in a derived class, handles the clicking of the up button on the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

public abstract void UpButton ();

UpdateEditText()

When overridden in a derived class, updates the text displayed in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

protected abstract void UpdateEditText ();

ValidateEditText()

When overridden in a derived class, validates the text displayed in the spin box (also known as an up-down control).

protected virtual void ValidateEditText ();

Remarks

Some examples of validation include comparing the text entered to the data type set in your derived class, comparing the text to a list of values, or verifying the text to be within a range of values.

WndProc(Message)

Processes Windows messages.

protected override void WndProc (ref System.Windows.Forms.Message m);
m
Message

The Windows Message to process.

Events

AutoSizeChanged

Occurs when the value of the stem.Windows.Forms.UpDownBase.AutoSize* property changes.

public event EventHandler AutoSizeChanged;

Remarks

For more information about handling events, see Events.

BackgroundImageChanged
